headline.main: Anniversary Dinner of the Association of the Alumni of the University of New-York.

docs.lead_paragraph: The twenty-first annual dinner of the above-named Association came off, last evening, at the Astor House. The dinner was served in the Ladies' Ordinary of the hotel, and was just of that kind which, to accurately describe, imposes upon us the necessity of saying, what for years has been a stereotyped expression when speaking of the dinners got up in the cuisine of COLEMAN STETSON--that "it comprised all the delicacies of the...

headline.main: THE SOUTH.; Letters on the Productions, Industry and Resources of the Slace States. NUMBER TWENTY-SEVEN.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Moral and Intellectual Culture of the Negro in Slavery--Evidence of a Missionary--How the South has Failed of its Duty--What Business this of Our's. In discussing the views presented in my last letter with Southerners, the labors of a society for the religious instruction of negroes in Liberty Country, Georgia, have frequently been referred to as an instance of the great privileges which the negroes may be blessed with in Slavery.

byline.original: SPECIAL CORRESPONDENCE OF THE N. Y. DAILY TIMES

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The question now agitated, of the propriety of setting apart,on this island, certain plots of ground for a public park, is one of no ordinary interest to its inhabitants;
docs.snippet: To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The question now agitated, of the propriety of setting apart,on this island, certain plots of ground for a public park, is one of no ordinary interest to its inhabitants;

headline.main: RIO JANEIRO.; Yellow Fever--Deaths among the Diplomatic Corps--Prevalence of Disease, &c.

docs.lead_paragraph: You have no doubt seen frequent notices of the presence of the yellow fever here since 1849; and have, with the world at large, very possibly supposed that the mortality was principally confined to the sailors, and others of the poorer classes, who could not command proper medical attention.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I read, with much interest, the recent communication in the TIMES, upon the subject which heads this article. Many have read it with that sympathetic interest which attaches to every benevolent and philanthropic enterprise, rising upon the agitated sea of human toil and struggle, self-seeking aggrandizement, ambitions graspings, and sectarian clashing and slashing.

docs.lead_paragraph: BOARD OF HEALTH--Tuesday.--Present, Mayor Lambert and Aldermen, Morris, Neely and Hinman. The First District Health Warden complained of a cesspool in the yard in the rear of the Post-Office, constituting an offensive nuisance.
docs.snippet: BOARD OF HEALTH--Tuesday.--Present, Mayor Lambert and Aldermen, Morris, Neely and Hinman. The First District Health Warden complained of a cesspool in the yard in the rear of the Post-Office, constituting an offensive nuisance.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the fields! The tide flows outward; away from nauseous streets, rowdyism, bad government, and away from the thronging thousands who are already in motion for the City; away from pestilence and torrid heat, and close corners, where respiration becomes a science, and motion a mystery.
